Ray Levoi.Action: Pulls out of a threatening traffic jam and races on the narrow right between thirty cars and a cement girder.
Greets Louis warmly with 'Louis, my man, what's happenin'?', displaying friendliness.
Calmly pours coffee and watches the bust with hands in pockets, making a detached, almost flippant comment 'Slam dunk.'
Calmly pours coffee, opens Sweet n'Low, and watches the FBI bust confidently while others react with surprise and nervousness.
Sets his briefcase on the counter and confidently interacts with the fence man, showing knowledge of the bonds.
Does not immediately react to the FBI raid with alarm or panic but maintains composure and confidence.
Fidgeting nervously with briefcase latches before opening it, showing some signs of nervousness.
Tells Carl that he stole from his country and shows no hesitation in confronting betrayal.
Walks briskly toward the door after being called by an authority, showing no emotional engagement with Carl's disbelief and hurt.
Confronts Carl calmly and confidently, exposing Carl's hypocrisy and theft.
Responds thoughtfully to Louis's message about being wanted upstairs, then quickly acts on it without hesitation.
Pauses momentarily while holding the doorknob, processing the significance of Louis's words, showing presence of mind.
Greets others politely with firm handshakes and acknowledges honor in meeting Agent Couture.
Politely declines coffee offered by Tully.
Walks into a firm handshake with Number-Two-in-Command Tully, and politely declines coffee, showing professional manners.
Sits nervously across from a veteran agent who studies him skeptically, suggesting a lack of confidence or established credibility.
Introduces himself clearly and respectfully, acknowledges the veteran agent with 'It's an honor,' demonstrating respectful communication skills.
Shows confusion and defers to superiors when reassigned to South Dakota, asking if he did something wrong.
Engages politely and respectfully in conversation with superiors about his heritage and new assignment.
Asked if he had done something unsatisfactory after being reassigned, showing some uncertainty.
Acknowledges his mixed heritage with hesitation and uncertainty about details.
Listens attentively to explanation regarding the sensitive assignment in South Dakota and the complexities involved.
Acknowledges his limited Native American heritage but expresses discomfort with being labeled fully as Indian.
Looks unsure and uneasy when confronted with his assignment to Indian Country and the expectations associated with his heritage.
Expresses uncertainty and hesitation about claiming Indian identity and entering Indian Country assignment, showing lack of confidence.
Sits before files and photos looking unsure, indicating initial insecurity about new assignment despite its importance.
Works through folders of case files methodically while traveling, showing engagement and diligence in his task.
Compliments partner on surviving dangerous past events without injury, showing a friendly and respectful attitude.
Demonstrates situational awareness by observing the harsh environment and conditions of the reservation, reflecting an understanding of the context he is entering.
Makes a confident remark about surviving dangerous past assignments without showing signs of injury, indicating experience and self-assurance.
Expresses visible consternation after initial observations, which may suggest concern or uncertainty about the mission or surroundings.
Squats a safe distance from the body, covering his nose with a kerchief while looking in the file.
Accepts the case and coordinates call signals with Cooch, showing readiness to proceed independently.
Carefully approaches Cooch to share observation, studies evidence calmly and documents thoroughly with photos.
Engages with Cooch cooperatively, showing respectful and patient demeanor while examining the scene.
No dismissive or hostile behavior toward Cooch or surroundings; reacts with curiosity and seriousness.
Carefully approaches Cooch and studies the ground where a strange symbol is found.
Hefts up a camera and starts methodically taking photos from different angles of the evidence.
Expresses an understanding that the marks on the victim are from a serious weapon at close range, showing insight.
Steps out cautiously with weapon drawn but held at ease, studies Crow Horse before taking action.
Frisks Crow Horse, disarms him by finding a gun in his possession.
Approaches suspicious figure cautiously with weapon drawn but held at ease, performs frisk thoroughly and finds concealed gun.
Intervenes to enforce restricted area but allows situation to be checked by superior (Cooch).
Offers a hand to help Crow Horse get up after taunting.
Nods back respectfully to Crow Horse's repeated nods, engaging in a culturally meaningful gesture.
Stares uneasily at Crow Horse, delays directly answering when asked about the journey Leo must take.
Assures Crow Horse that Leo will have his hands because he needs them for quillwork, showing some respect for cultural practices.
Stares at Crow Horse after he speaks in Sioux without responding, indicating possible discomfort or detachment.
Shows hesitation and unease when confronted by Crow Horse about Leo's journey and jurisdiction issues.
Affirms that Leo needs to take the journey but defers to completing investigation first, showing procedural adherence but some lack of decisiveness.
Responds quickly to Crow Horse's comment about Leo needing his hands, demonstrating awareness and quick thinking.
Comments with mild curiosity about the 'Keeping of the Souls Ceremony' indicating an openness to another culture.
Acknowledges the exclusionary sign 'No Indians Allowed' along with Cooch, showing awareness but does not confront it.
Observes cultural practices without questioning or trying to understand deeper.
Allows himself to be sidelined (asked to wait in the car) showing lack of assertiveness in a potentially difficult social situation.
Greets Clear Moon quickly and respectfully, smiles, and shakes his hand with sincerity.
Shows attentiveness and respect toward Clear Moon's concerns and leads as they approach the motel.
Refuses raw kidney offered by Clear Moon politely, says 'I'm set.'
Looks over shoulder threateningly at Cooch after Cooch winks and pats his back.
Observes quietly the locals harassing the Indian man outside, without intervening.
Gets out of bed quickly and moves to window upon hearing glass break and laughter, showing alertness and concern.
Keeps the dizzy and exhausted Indian man from falling after he stumbles.
Fails to prevent the Indian man from getting punched after pushing him forward.
Stands tense and watches Cooch handle the situation without taking more direct control or intervening decisively.
Maintains composure when unexpectedly identified as FBI along with Cooch; does not flinch or show signs of being caught off guard.
Openly admits to selling liquor on the reservation as a cover story, demonstrating some street smarts and preparation.
Engages smoothly in casual conversation with locals to maintain cover and gather information.
Asks if the men knew Leo Fast Elk, showing curiosity and attempting to gather information relevant to the investigation.
Watches the men leave, curious and observant, indicating attentiveness and engagement.
Cracks a laugh watching Cooch's exaggerated steps and singing, showing relaxed camaraderie.
Engages in socializing and making efforts to 'penetrate' and 'infiltrate' the community by talking to locals.
Keeps a serious and intense demeanor while driving and preparing to meet locals.
Already got the plate numbers off all the cars before being asked.
Shows familiarity with recording equipment and accepts a delicate task (social infiltration) with confidence.
Practices introducing himself using a difficult name to prepare for interaction.
Attempts to speak politely at door, using full name from cheat sheet.
Waits patiently without immediate reaction when door is closed and locked.
Looks through hole in door and acknowledges presence with 'Sir?'.
Turns away with a flustered sigh but then quickly notices something across the road and reacts with concern.
Walks calmly toward Crow Horse and observes him feel tracking without interrupting initially.
Attempts to get Crow Horse’s attention by saying 'Hey' more than once but is ignored.
Struggles to correctly remember the name Hobert Buffalo-Dreaming, needing to consult a cheat sheet; door is locked on him.
Notices something troubling across the road, removes his shades to get a better look, and promptly hurries to investigate.
Attempts to get Crow Horse's attention but is ignored, potentially indicating difficulty asserting authority or presence here.
Observes Crow Horse’s skilled tracking without interfering, demonstrating restraint and awareness of another's competencies.
Dismisses Crow Horse's detailed tracking skills with skepticism and uses dismissive language.
Asserts authority by telling Crow Horse to leave a restricted area.
Dismisses Crow Horse's detailed tracking skills with skepticism and challenges his expertise.
Attempts to assert legal authority by telling Crow Horse to leave a restricted area despite the cultural significance of the land.
Dismisses Crow Horse's cultural knowledge and ridicules spiritual beliefs, using sarcastic and insulting language.
Warns Crow Horse firmly that if his partner finds him, there will be consequences, but eventually lets him leave without escalating the conflict.
Calls Crow Horse 'Fuck you' after deliberation.
Tries to ask Maisy Blue Legs questions politely despite her telling him to go away.
Scrutinizes Crow Horse carefully, deliberates before speaking.
Stands frozen, blown away, seeming unable to respond effectively.
Surveys the scene at Maisy Blue Legs' house methodically, follows tire tracks to investigate.
Sweating under his jacket, uncertain whether amazed or pissed off, indicating some internal confusion.
Attempts to question Maisy Blue Legs politely and persistently despite her rebuff.
Tries to appeal to Maisy by revealing his identity as Sioux and Indian in an attempt to gain trust and connection.
Responds with frustration and disbelief when Maisy shuts the door on him.
Shows careful attention and sensitivity by examining the muddy boots and environment quietly, indicating empathy and concern.
Kills the rattlesnake aggressively and loudly, which may indicate urgency to protect but could be perceived as harsh or unsettling.
Immediately reacts with concern upon hearing crying and moaning inside the trailer, verbally reassures Mrs. Blue Legs that 'It's okay!'
Expresses relief when Cooch shares crucial information, calls Cooch 'my hero'.
Finds the location of Leo and quickly relays the information over the radio, showing situational awareness and prompt communication.
Expresses relief when COOCH reveals he has the suspect, showing trust and ability to coordinate with colleagues effectively.
Seems rushed and anxious after dealing with the dead snake, but manages to hurry out to continue the mission, indicating determination despite stress.
Expresses desire for personal confrontation ('I'd just like five minutes alone with the motherfucker who hung that flag upside down.')
Shows great interest in understanding tribal conflicts and symbols.
Stares down the Indian youth with M-16 trained at him, orders him to get on the ground.
Looks dumbfounded and unnerved by the sweat lodge and native ceremony noises.
Maneuvers toward the house with rifles ready, maintains control when confronting the Indian youth door tender, staring him down confidently to get compliance.
Reacting with confusion and unease to the sweat lodge and chanting sounds, whispering 'What the hell is that?'
Cuts off the old man speaking in Lakota instead of listening.
Gently takes the old man's thin arm and locks eyes to get him to comply.
Explains their FBI identity and need to ask questions, attempting to communicate.
Allows Grandpa Reaches to look at him meaningfully and says 'Go ahead' indicating reluctant tolerance or permission.
Hesitates briefly before firing wildly into the area to find suspect.
Starts toward injured Cooch to assist after he is badly mauled.
Runs tirelessly to search for missing suspect, showing concern by picking up Jimmy's towel and looking carefully.
Hesitates briefly before firing to scatter the suspect’s path, demonstrating calculated decision-making under pressure.
Searches the area intensively by throwing the flashlight in multiple directions, crossing a river, and sprinting through the field, showing persistence and thoroughness.
Mistakes a deer for the suspect and nearly fires, indicating a momentary lapse in judgment or situational awareness.
Talks to the elders on the reservation, showing them photos of Jimmy despite getting no response.
Sheds his jacket and tie and stands sweat-drenched, indicating effort and respect in a tense situation.
Responds to Crow Horse's mocking remark with a light-hearted comeback.
Quickly leaves the porch to follow a lead given by an Indian informant, showing openness and willingness to engage.
Shows photos to the elders to gather information despite no immediate response.
Interacts calmly and confidently with Walter Crow Horse despite tense circumstances.
Quickly acts on new information by leaving promptly to follow up on a lead.
Listens attentively and looks intrigued by Grandpa Samuel Reaches' words and actions.
Leans on the wall looking uncomfortable in the room.
Fidgets and asks what is smoked in the sacred pipe, showing curiosity but some unease.
Takes the sacred pipe but then passes it back without smoking, potentially signaling hesitation or mistrust.
Smirks when Grandpa speaks and questions Crow Horse skeptically about translation.
Engages with Grandpa's barter by hesitantly exchanging his sunglasses for the necklace.
Asks Crow Horse to ask the Spirits about the murderer, showing initiative and focus on the mission.
Smirks during a serious spiritual ceremony, indicating a casual or possibly disrespectful attitude.
Shows interest and patience listening to Grandpa's long oratory and signs.
Questions Crow Horse insistently about the meaning of the speech, demonstrating engagement and critical thinking.
Reluctantly agrees to trade his sunglasses for Grandpa's necklace, showing willingness to engage with local customs despite hesitation.
Exhibits some hesitation and slowness in accepting the trade, suggesting a degree of uncertainty or lack of confidence.
Slowly, hesitantly surrenders his sunglasses and takes the necklace from Grandpa after the trade.
Queries Crow Horse repeatedly, showing curiosity about what Grandpa said and what the owl means.
Makes a sarcastic comment about using the owl as evidence in Federal Court, showing skepticism.
Looks confused and out of his element during the negotiation and trade with Grandpa.
Fails to grasp the cultural and symbolic meaning of the owl as explained by Crow Horse, responding with sarcasm and disbelief.
Attempts to engage with Crow Horse by asking questions despite the latter's dismissive attitude.
Stands silently and watches the flag ceremony with solemnity and respect.
Acknowledges President Clear Moon respectfully, listens to his concerns, and tries to reassure him by saying the warriors can lead them to Jimmy and asking to let them go.
Politely greets President Clear Moon and listens to his urgent concerns about the danger posed by the 'new Indians.'
Attempts to negotiate by suggesting letting the Warriors go to help lead agents to Jimmy, showing tactical thinking.
Shows calm and understanding in a tense situation involving hostile Warriors and the fearful tribal president.
Does not assert authority aggressively, instead tries to de-escalate carefully, which may be positive but could be seen as hesitant if reading critically.
Stakes out Jimmy's house discreetly with appropriate weapons, showing vigilance and readiness.
Stands silently and thoughtfully facing Yellow Bird without reacting emotionally or dismissively, showing self-control and situational awareness.
Does not respond to the Indian wit about the Washington Redskin, missing an opportunity to engage or defuse tension.
Breaks off a piece of sandwich and drops it to a mangy dog outside the van.
Confronts Maggie Eagle Bear aggressively with a weapon drawn, commanding her to comply.
Notices the suspicious truck and communicates clearly over the radio to coordinate the operation.
Takes tactical approach by sliding low, using cover, and positioning himself skillfully to intercept the subject.
Commands the suspect assertively with clear verbal orders during apprehension.
Surprised to discover the suspect is a woman but maintains caution.
Looks self-conscious in the cowboy hat, responding humbly to Maggie's compliment about his approach.
Bends down to untie and examine the dropped bundle carefully, showing respect for Maggie's belongings and cultural items.
Engages in conversation with Maggie using gentle humor ('Is that like an hereditary thing, Magdelana, or can one take classes?').
Focuses on gathering information and understanding motives while mindful of the community context and possible consequences.
Frisks Maggie one-handed and pats down her boots carefully.
Looks self-conscious in the cowboy hat, indicating some discomfort or lack of confidence in appearance.
Carefully looks down to find and untie the dropped bundle, showing attentiveness and respect for cultural items.
Asks intelligent questions about Jimmy's abilities and background, showing curiosity and engagement.
Acknowledges the serious danger of the situation by referencing the Fugitive Alert to prevent further violence.
Engages in a respectful and patient conversation with Maggie, despite underlying tensions.
Does not dismiss or ignore cultural elements such as the medicine bundle, showing cultural sensitivity.
Deliberates then hands over the medicine bundle to Maggie, showing respect for its power.
Uses Maggie's first name when speaking, indicating some familiarity or connection.
Admits a cultural difference but engages in conversation with Maggie sincerely.
Tells Maggie to tell Jimmy to turn himself in to back off the reservation, showing concern for peace.
Deliberates before handing over the medicine bundle, showing respect for its power despite not fully understanding it.
Admits he doesn't have a clue about the radical ideas Maggie refers to, showing awareness of his own limits.
Uses cultural knowledge and confident communication to try to influence Jimmy to turn himself in and de-escalate the situation.
Seems unsure or surprised when Maggie uses his first name and questions his cultural background, indicating some social discomfort.
Questions and then releases Eagle Bear instead of detaining her.
Returns the medicine bundle to Eagle Bear so she can take it to Jimmy.
Takes a white eagle feather as evidence carefully and respectfully.
Uses knowledge of local culture (medicine bundle, eagle feather) in his work, indicating respect and understanding.
Does not question or challenge Cooch's manipulative tactics to create discord among the Warrior Movement.
Offers milk to the dog to drink, sharing what he has.
Pulls his hat down low and sits back when Crow Horse approaches, showing avoidance.
Removes his hat as a sign of respect to avoid provoking Crow Horse.
Responds to Crow Horse's cultural greeting with a rude gesture but in a joking manner.
Engages in friendly banter and shares important information about the case sincerely.
Remains calm and chooses not to escalate conflict after Crow Horse insults him with a middle finger.
Removes his hat deliberately to avoid provoking Crow Horse at the shooting range.
Uses humor and irony to defuse tension (‘Forgive my cultural ignorance’ and a joking retaliatory gesture).
Shows insight and awareness by acknowledging the genetic link between the eagle feathers and suspects in the investigation.
Engages thoughtfully in conversation and listens carefully to Crow Horse's story, showing interest and consideration.
Replies somewhat skeptically ('That's not solid.') but without dismissiveness or rudeness.
Repeats an elaborate story about a shooting with a focus on technical detail ('Electromagnetic printing').
Fails to immediately grasp the logical inconsistency pointed out by Crow Horse about Jimmy Looks Twice being petrified of cars yet purportedly firing from a moving vehicle.
Shows interest and attentiveness to Crow Horse's explanation, absorbing it with 'great interest'.
Takes out his notebook and starts writing down Crow Horse's observations about the crime scene.
Laughs at Crow Horse missing all the targets while shooting but quickly recognizes Crow Horse's seriousness and follows him attentively.
Smirks as Crow Horse nervously speaks of a vision about Ray's possible death.
Looks nervous when Grandpa wants to trade his expensive Rolex watch for a cigarette, then politely refuses the trade explaining the watch's value.
Expresses skepticism and dismisses Native American beliefs as myths, emphasizing his role as an FBI agent over cultural understanding.
Admits he appreciates Crow Horse's effort to help despite disagreeing, showing some recognition and politeness.
Questions the validity of local beliefs and insists on a professional, fact-based approach.
Expresses frustration and dismisses the cultural context as myths, showing limited cultural sensitivity.
Shows confidence in wanting to do his job right and get out quickly.
Reactively knocks away Crow Horse's gesture, indicating impulsive emotional reaction.
Engages in yelling and defensive posturing with Crow Horse, then gives a rude hand gesture before leaving.
Ends the interaction with 'Take care of yourself, Walter.'
Yelling and ready to fight with Crow Horse but becomes bewildered and does not escalate the situation; ultimately leaves calmly and sarcastically gestures goodbye.
Challenges the assumption about the suspect and uses cultural knowledge to advocate for the right man.
Jokes about smoking kinickinick to deflect teasing from other agents.

Uses logic and local knowledge to challenge the assumption that Jimmy Looks Twice is the culprit, pointing out inconsistencies in the official theory based on Jimmy's fear of driving and unique walking pattern.

Faces skepticism and mild ridicule from other agents but remains confident and informative about local cultural practices (correcting the joking comment about 'hooch' with accurate knowledge about kinickinick).
Feeds a stray dog and tries to take care of it despite difficulties.
Expresses concern about the way a victim was killed and a desire to protect others.
Shows willingness to listen and reconcile with Cooch after being chastised.
Follows Cooch after a nod, gathering paperwork and showing determination like a terrier.
Asks about new evidence indicating attentiveness.
Feeds a dog in the van and is unable to get rid of it, showing some distraction.
Expresses concern about his first homicide case and wants to prevent future mistakes, showing emotional engagement but some uncertainty.
Reassures Cooch that he's not pulling against him after being criticized for acting on his own.
Thanks Cooch after a brief exchange, shows patience with the confused dog by pulling it out but allows it to run after him.
Sits quietly behind the wheel, listening to a woman singing a traditional song without disturbing or interrupting.
Does not react aggressively to the dog's growling, instead quietly observes and waits until it calms.
Follows Cooch's instruction to tail Eagle Bear and stay with her, showing willingness to take orders and act accordingly.
Follows Cooch's request to get rid of the dog calmly despite the dog's confused and growling behavior, showing control and composure.
Sits quietly behind the wheel, lost in thought and seemingly distracted while on a stakeout.
Throws himself low to avoid gunfire, then aggressively defends by unloading his M-16 while lying low and listening carefully.
Slides out of the van belly first under heavy gunfire, grips his M-16 and crawls into cover.
Pops up ten feet away and unloads his M-16 in a disciplined left-to-right sweep before dropping again.
Listens carefully after firing to assess the quiet, showing situational awareness.
Looks haggard and tired after the action.

Steps out of the vehicle immediately upon spotting something suspicious, maintains focused observation across the terrain, and physically investigates the area with Cooch using gloves and tools methodically.
Interrupts Cooch to enforce caution and control over the conversation when emotions run high, demonstrating restraint and leadership.
Displays informed speculation about Maggie’s behavior, interpreting signals that others might miss, showing insight and analytical thinking.
Appears haggard and somewhat resigned while drinking coffee before the discovery, potentially indicating fatigue affecting performance.
Stares intently and shows patience while assessing the scene, thoughtful about the environment and situation.
Hesitates when entering the motel room, snagged by the sight of a motorcycle under a discriminatory sign, indicating sensitivity to injustice.
Correctly identifies that the site is not a dry wash but part of the Little Walking River, demonstrating his observational skills and local knowledge.
Notices environmental details such as the presence of water and heat undulations, showing focused attention and awareness.
Hesitates upon seeing the motorcycle parked under the 'NO INDIANS' sign, indicating alertness and suspicion.
Approaches Crow Horse carefully, shows concern over his drunken state, and confronts him honestly.
Uses blunt language ('Cut the shit', 'don't give a goddamn') but with intent to protect and express frustration.
Responds calmly to Crow Horse's accusations despite anger, defends his integrity and identity as both Indian and good cop.
Glares at Crow Horse and shows visible anger after being insulted and threatened.
Successfully defends himself by quickly disarming the Rancher's Son with skillful, targeted punches and a well-executed roundhouse kick.
Tries to verbally de-escalate the situation initially but is quickly overwhelmed and forced to fight.
Avoids answering the Rancher's Son's question about his heritage, maintaining a tense and unreadable demeanor.

Quietly seethes and shows internal conflict while driving, but does not lash out.
Knocks the tray out of the bar man's hand, spilling drinks on locals and causing confusion.
Analyzes evidence about plates, registration, serial numbers removed, and prints washed off and comments sarcastically on the case being a 'walk in the park'.
Responds promptly and listens carefully over the radio, remembers the upside down flag incident, and reacts to new intel about the fire at his motel room.
Keeps driving silently upon hearing Maggie is causing trouble, showing no emotional reaction or engagement.
Stands apart from the group watching silently; does not join prayers at a grave despite invitation.
Insists Maggie join him for a ride to Rapid City instead of joining the group prayer.
Confronts Maggie about burning an American flag and accuses her of desecration, showing a critical and confrontational stance.
Stands firm and silent when Maggie approaches, maintaining a composed presence on the hill.
Initiates taking Maggie to Rapid City firmly and directly.
Engages Maggie in a tense conversation revealing manipulation and conflict, but does not respond defensively or lose control.
Does not join the prayer at the grave despite Maggie's invitation.
Shows a hunger or desire for power seen by Maggie, which may cloud his judgment or lead to manipulative behavior.
Shares a personal story about his father using Indian words, revealing a soft and humorous side.
Presses Maggie for information about the photos despite her reluctance, showing insistence but also vulnerability in asking for help.
Accepts Maggie’s half-smile and survival humor without anger, showing tolerance and a quiet respect.
Leaves Maggie standing alone after a tense exchange without further reassurance or connection.
Carefully shuffles and examines multiple polaroids, looking for useful information.
Attempts to get information by confronting Maggie, but she stonewalls him; he studies her reaction thoughtfully.
Keeps composure after being mocked about meaning of 'Washee' with quiet humor rather than frustration.
After failing to get Maggie’s help, pauses to think deeply and reflects quietly before leaving.
Leaves Maggie without pushing further or showing signs of panic or loss of control.
Reflects soberly on historical injustices, showing empathy and awareness.
Concerned about Maggie and the children, watching them protectively from the window.
Approaches the burial grounds slowly despite rain, drawn to them with respect and sincerity.
Leaves his gun in the car, not prepared to use violence initially.
Thinks hard while reviewing files and photographs, showing focus on his task.
Gets flustered and distracted by the date 1868, indicating momentary confusion or lapse.
Steps out into harsh weather to approach burial grounds despite discomfort, showing determination and resolve.
Forgets his gun in the car, leaving himself defenseless in a threatening situation.
Attempts to react and run when threatened by an armed horseman, showing quick thinking under sudden threat though caught unprepared.
Keeps running past an Indian woman crying and clutching a baby, despite seeing her distress.
Shows physical panic and fear while fleeing a pursuer.
Responds briefly and apologetically to Cooch’s concern about his safety.
Approaches Grandpa and sincerely apologizes, saying 'I'm sorry.'
Walks away quickly and leaves after Grandpa sings and shares powerful cultural history, showing discomfort and avoidance.
Looks sick and disturbed by Grandpa's story, struggles to process the significance and almost freezes, then quickly leaves the situation to avoid dealing with it further.

Questions Cooch about the sudden military escalation and federal occupation, showing concern for the implications.
Acts tired and feverish but tries to maintain composure around colleagues.

Appears tired and feverish, not fully present or physically well, which may impair his effectiveness.

Knocks on the door politely and waits for Yellow Bird to open it.
Asks Yellow Bird about his wheelchair and prison experience, engaging sincerely in conversation.
Maintains respectful tone by using Yellow Bird’s first name and explaining reasons for visit patiently.
Presses Yellow Bird about a problematic arrangement, showing directness but no evident insensitivity.

Engages Yellow Bird with direct and clear questions about his past and the arrangement, demonstrating control of the conversation and purpose.
Walks around the room observing covertly while maintaining dialogue, showing situational awareness and skill.
Repeatedly uses the suspect's name and references official sources (Washington) to establish authority and rapport.
Firmly insists Yellow Bird stand up and walk despite Yellow Bird's leg injury and distress.
Explains the consequences of Yellow Bird's failure to uphold parole agreement clearly and without personal animosity.
Calmly controls a tense situation with Yellow Bird, giving clear instructions and maintaining authority.
Uses firm but measured commands to get Yellow Bird to comply despite resistance and emotional outburst.
Demonstrates understanding of the legal stakes and enforces the consequences logically (early parole conditions and transport).
Does not escalate conflict with Yellow Bird, showing patience and control.
Snaps out his gun and assertively claims authority.
Stops and looks back at Yellow Bird in distress before leaving.
Offers a shared acknowledgment of pain ('You and me both').
Waves slightly to the regional agent before getting in the car.
Grabs onto Yellow Bird's words silently, assessing the situation before acting.
Snaps out his gun decisively and asserts authority by saying, 'I'm the fucking law!'
Observes Yellow Bird slipping into despair and chooses to leave quietly after a brief, empathetic comment.
Does not follow up or offer aid to Yellow Bird after he collapses in pain, instead leaves the scene.
Drives recklessly at high speed through dangerous terrain, attempting to evade a tail.
Uses a sharp turn and pulls off the road quickly to lose his pursuer, successfully escaping.
Loses control of the car, crashes into a fence, but ultimately manages to confirm he lost the car behind him.
Steps out cautiously and studies the tomb at the Wounded Knee Memorial carefully, showing attention to detail and purpose.
Clears overgrown weeds from the tombstone names with frantic abandon, showing determination and focus to reveal important information.
Stares at the name 'Thunder Heart' with fear and backs away quickly, then leaves the scene rapidly.
Responds immediately and physically defends himself when attacked at Maggie Eagle Bear's house, quickly gaining control and using his gun and flashlight effectively.
Tries to calmly explain to Crow Horse that he is not taking Maggie anywhere and is trying to find her.
Attempts to convince Crow Horse to come with him to follow old man's instructions, showing concern for cooperation.
Engages in a sincere conversation about dreams and visions, showing openness and interest in Crow Horse's culture and experiences.
Attempts to calm and reason with Crow Horse by explaining his intentions and asking him to come along to follow the old man's instructions.
Maintains control over a tense situation by keeping Crow Horse restrained and holding a gun, displaying situational awareness and assertiveness.
Engages Crow Horse in conversation about visions and shares personal dream details to build understanding and trust.
Initially downplays the significance of his dream ('Well, it was just a dream, I --'), potentially showing a lack of full confidence or insight into the cultural/spiritual importance of the vision.
Stops the vehicle promptly when Crow Horse says 'Stop'.
Observes Crow Horse's ritual and respectfully participates by dropping a cigarette alongside the tobacco offering.
Expresses confusion and frustration with 'What the hell do you want me to do?!'
Stops to drop a cigarette next to Crow Horse's offering before continuing.
Acts with concern and alarm when discovering the uranium strip-mining holes and discusses the environmental threat sincerely.
Identifies and interprets uranium drilling test holes from subtle environmental clues, showing understanding of their significance.
Falls into a hidden hole due to unseen environmental danger, indicating a momentary lapse in caution.
Steps back in disbelief and covers his mouth, showing emotional reaction to finding Maggie Eagle Bear's body.
Explodes yelling after discovering the body, expressing deep anguish and emotional investment.
Looks almost hurt when Crow Horse says Clear Moon doesn't trust the white man; takes a long breath, acknowledges his own mixed identity, and tries to steady himself.
Sits tense, hands shaking, while waiting outside Clear Moon's house, showing vulnerability and respect for the situation.
Despite shaky hands and visible nervousness, manages to light a cigarette and stay alert, watching his rearview mirror carefully.
Looks almost hurt and internalizes Crow Horse's distrust of white men, showing emotional vulnerability but not losing composure.
Pushes open Yellow Bird's shack door despite potential danger, showing concern for a troubled figure important to the tribe.
Communicates cautiously and calmly over radio after sensing tension, displaying steadiness and responsibility.
Stares quietly at the empty shack and the vast plains, showing internal struggle and emotional weight but does not withdraw from responsibility.
Insists on going back in to finish something with Crow Horse despite the risks.
Leaves Crow Horse behind as he recklessly drives off alone.
Decides to return to the council fire despite warnings, showing determination and focus on his objective.
Drives recklessly down a rutted road, leaving his companion behind and possibly risking safety.
Appears shell-shocked and physically battered but still manages to clean up and prepare himself, showing resilience and mental endurance.
Keeps quiet and dry when questioned about his bruises, indicating control and composure under pressure.
Goes back to confront Crow Horse and suffers a bruise, showing persistence and willingness to engage directly.
Lunges at and physically assaults his superior officer Cooch in anger, demonstrating poor impulse control and a lack of professional judgment.
Questions his superior about the true nature of their operation and exposes awareness of a cover-up involving environmental and human harm, indicating insight and moral courage.
Remains silent and recoils after being threatened, showing some restraint under pressure.
Questions official orders and expresses concern about the impact on Native people, showing moral awareness and critical thinking.
Leans on the sink, appears contemplative and hesitant before proceeding with the operation.
Does not immediately respond or engage when SA Miles enters, possibly indicating distraction or passive behavior.
Stops and silently acknowledges Tribal President Clear Moon's greeting and approval despite internal horror and confusion.
Panics and recklessly speeds away, causing confusion and potential danger to others.
Stops dead and stares speechless and horrified upon seeing Clear Moon unexpectedly.
Nods vaguely, showing uncertainty and hesitation before walking away.
Panics, looks at his watch anxiously, then starts the car and drives recklessly with swerving and hard turns.
Cuts a hard U-turn abruptly and speeds toward the reservation, surprising the other agents.
Leaves trailers and transitional developments behind while closely watching the road and rearview mirror, showing attentive vigilance.
Runs into the Badlands to find and help the injured Crow Horse, physically supporting him out of danger despite personal risk.
Urgently encourages Crow Horse to leave the reservation to save their lives, showing protective and caring behavior.
Keeps driving steadily with injured Crow Horse half-passed out beside him, focused on their safety despite radio calls or distractions.
Runs into a damaged trailer with concern, then quickly decides to evade the approaching federal cars to protect himself and Crow Horse.
Acknowledges the futility of the situation with Crow Horse, showing shared understanding without blame or hostility.
Acts decisively and urgently under pressure, but no explicit indication of friendliness or trustworthiness toward others in this excerpt.
Leaps out of the car, runs toward the trailer with gun in hand, investigating the scene despite danger.
Shakes his head to indicate the person is gone after checking the trailer, showing quick assessment skills.
Hesitates before getting back into the car when he sees three federal cars approaching, showing caution.
Drives like a maniac trying to evade the federal cars, demonstrates decisive action under pressure.
States confidently to Crow Horse that they are going for The Stronghold despite being surrounded, demonstrating confidence and decisiveness.
Plays a recording to expose corruption and injustice, despite personal risk.
Expresses anger and defiance towards corrupt authority ('Fuck you').
Holds onto his gun longer than Crow Horse but ultimately complies and drops it without resistance.
Faces a heavily armed group calmly, showing a willingness to deescalate the situation without aggression.
Keeps calm and moves decisively when the windshield shatters and the Le Baron gets stuck; quickly bails out with guns drawn.
Holds onto his .45 even after Crow Horse drops his weapon, showing initial hesitation before finally complying with the command to drop the gun.
Does not attempt to escalate the standoff despite being heavily outnumbered and instead complies with orders to drop his weapon, avoiding unnecessary violence.
Refuses to come forward despite pressure from COOCH and surrounding armed agents.
Assesses the back-up situation calmly and recognizes the reality of the standoff, telling Cooch 'It's over.'
Maintains composure and confidence when confronted by Cooch's intense stare, holding his ground and shaking his head slowly.
Makes a strategic decision to 'Let the press through' despite Cooch's consternation, showing sound judgment and situational awareness.
Lays a pine cone in the ground with care, showing respect to the land.
Walks with Crow Horse, shares a friendly exchange of greetings and concern, showing openness and connection.
Expresses hope and concern for the community's future and water supply, indicating sincerity and care.
Carefully plants a pine cone in the ground, showing mindfulness and respect to the land.
Engages in meaningful conversation with Crow Horse about the community and future political change, showing awareness and involvement.
Expresses concern about the water and listens to Crow Horse's response, indicating thoughtful consideration of important issues.
Takes Crow Horse's hand, shifting from a white man's handshake to the Indian allies grip, showing cultural adaptability and social intelligence.
Ponders the future and admits uncertainty, showing openness but also a slight hesitance or lack of immediate direction.
Cracks a genuine smile after a subtle joke from Crow Horse.
Responds to Crow Horse's offer with respect, acknowledging no word for goodbye.
Strips off his Rolex and gives it to Grandpa without expecting anything in return.
Returns the smile after the silent done deal, showing mutual respect and warmth.
Acknowledges Grandpa's sacred Pipe with the done deal sign, showing respect for Sioux tradition.
Considers the old man thoughtfully before approaching him, showing openness and sincerity.
Wipes dust from the broken windshield without complaint, showing practical acceptance but no strong emotion.
Slows down the car passing Maggie Eagle Bear's home, acknowledging community presence without interaction.
Successfully communicates silently and respectfully with Grandpa using sign language to confirm a trade without words, showing cultural sensitivity and situational awareness.
Despite a broken windshield and engine troubles, manages to get the car started on the third try and continues his journey, demonstrating persistence and practical skill.
Does not react negatively or hastily when finding the sacred Pipe on the passenger seat but instead responds with a respectful gesture, showing emotional intelligence and respect for local customs.
Pauses to consider Grandpa before walking over to him, displaying patience and thoughtfulness.
Smiles and exchanges a personal, meaningful item (Rolex watch) with Grandpa without demanding or negotiating, indicating confidence and trustworthiness.
Greets Carl warmly, complimenting his tie and encouraging him to breathe deeply to calm down.
Adjusts Carl's tie and collar carefully and speaks quietly to reassure him.
Expresses concern and reflects seriously on the dangerous situation facing agents in Indian Country.
Engages in light-hearted banter with Cooch, sharing a smile and friendly teasing about bureaucratic culture.
Considers the dangerous and complex nature of the assignment, asks insightful questions about Cooch's background, shows awareness of cultural and operational challenges.
Engages in banter with Cooch that reveals both confidence and understanding of the stakes.
Does not display any outright mistakes or ignorance despite the difficult circumstances presented.
Turns the file over to Cooch, shares information calmly while investigating a dead body
Swats at flies near the corpse while examining it
Catches the stumbling Indian man twice to prevent him from falling.
Shoves the Indian man forward after catching him, indirectly leading to him being punched.
Looks tense and serious observing the hostile interaction, shows concern.
Smiles good-naturedly at Cooch's off-color joke, shows curiosity by asking about Leo Fast Elk, and watches locals with interest
Does not confront offensive language or attitudes expressed by others, remains passive in tense or derogatory exchanges
Shuffles through intelligence materials with great interest and recognizes the significance of the symbolic flag as a statement.
Expresses desire for personal revenge impulsively ('five minutes alone with the motherfucker who hung that flag upside down').
Follows Cooch's tactical advice to remain alert and be ready to engage with his weapon; loads his M-16 promptly and maneuvers silently toward target.
Firmly orders the old man to put his hands on his head and physically restrains him when he initially refuses, maintaining control of the situation despite the man's resistance.
Maintains eye contact and steady composure during a tense confrontation, showing confidence and control.
Engages respectfully but assertively in a culturally sensitive environment, demonstrating situational awareness and command presence.
Cuts off the old man who was speaking in Lakota, potentially showing impatience or a lack of cultural tact.
Prepares to use the federal master key instead of force to open the door, showing readiness to follow lawful procedures.
Gets knocked off balance by Jimmy Looks Twice's back kick and is forced to roll in the grass reacting to a sudden attack.
Ray understands the cultural practice of bringing tobacco as a gift to an elder and complies appropriately by producing a pack of Marlboro cigarettes.
Ray asks a relevant question about Grandpa Samuel Reaches, showing curiosity and attempt to understand his situation.
Looks uncomfortable leaning on the wall but remains composed and intrigued when Grandpa speaks, does not flinch when questioned about stopping the Inipi ceremony.
Seems puzzled by the cryptic messages about the Cookie Monster and Big Bird, showing some confusion.
Tenses brow and stares intently, trying to absorb complex cultural and spiritual information.
Fidgets and asks a question about the sacred pipe, indicating some discomfort or unfamiliarity with the cultural ritual.
Takes the sacred pipe as offered but then passes it back without smoking, potentially indicating hesitation or distrust.
Considers the crippled activist Yellow Bird carefully rather than mocking or dismissing him.
Does not laugh or join in the agents’ grins at Yellow Bird’s comment, maintaining a serious demeanor.
Returns Maggie Eagle Bear’s intense glare without backing down or showing friendliness.
Follows orders and stakes out Jimmy's place, showing professional diligence but no overt friendly or warm behavior.
Nods, impressed by explanation of internal infighting and trust issues.
Quiet, tired laugh expressing frustration and weariness about their assignment.
Chases away the reservation dog that tries to follow him to the van.
Offers milk to a three-legged dog in the van, laughs gently in disbelief, shakes his head.
Sits in field clothes, uses binoculars to observe Maggie's house at a distance, takes care of a three-legged dog by sharing milk and laughs gently.
Laughs at Crow Horse missing targets but follows him seriously and shows interest in his perspective.
Lets out a pent-up sigh acknowledging a difficult truth (a white man committed the murder).
Physically assaults the rancher's son after provocation.
Remains tense and does not answer when questioned about his ethnicity.
Struggles with what he's feeling and what he's supposed to feel when Maggie offers herself to be arrested; admits he believes Jimmy may be innocent but feels in over his head.
Just stares at Maggie in silence after she offers herself to be arrested instead of responding immediately.
Admits to Maggie that he thinks Jimmy's innocent and confesses he's in over his head.
Runs in panic and fear, looks incredulous but keeps running despite confusion.
Wakes up quickly from a disturbing dream, responds to Cooch's concern promptly and starts car engine to follow.
Shows some situational awareness by following Cooch quickly once awake and ready to act.
Stands in the doorway looking concerned at Grandpa, despite the tense situation.
Tells Sherman to put down the fragile turtleshell rattle, showing respect for cultural/spiritual items.
Grabs Sherman and slams him into the wall after Sherman crushes the turtleshell rattle.
Slammed Jimmy Looks Twice against the wall and frisked him aggressively, showing no care for his desperation.
Stands near Cooch looking abhorred as Jimmy is pushed into the car, indicating some internal discomfort or reluctance.
Drives recklessly to evade pursuers, then stops at the Wounded Knee Memorial and quietly studies the tombstone.
Clears weeds frantically to reveal names on the tombstone, showing care and respect for the memory of those buried.
Pounds repeatedly on Maggie Eagle Bear's door, calling her name persistently, indicating concern and urgency.
Defends himself quickly and aggressively when attacked, using force and a gun to subdue the attacker.
Drops a cigarette next to Crow Horse's tobacco offering as a gesture of sharing or respect.
Expresses frustration with 'What the hell do you want me to do?!'
Refuses to come forward despite pressure and potential danger, standing his ground with resolve.
Does not take defensive or evasive action when surrounded by armed agents and under threat.
Acknowledges the end of the standoff and encourages letting the press through despite tension.
Stands his ground calmly in a tense situation, showing steadiness and respect.
